title: Family of 13 gypsies can build shower block after decade of sharing single tiny toilet
text:

A family of 13 Romany gypsies who have been sharing one tiny toilet for ten years have been given permission to build a bigger shower block.

The large Price family have been living on a developed part of Olive Tree Park in Cheadle, Staffordshire for more than ten years.

In that time David and Johanna, their three sons, their spouses and six grandchildren have had to make do with one toilet between them, Stoke Sentinel reported .

Now, following a decade long tussle with the local council, the Price family have been given permission to extend the current amenity building.

The new, larger building will contain a shower, toilet and a day room.

(Image: StokeOnTrentLive/ WS)

The application has been rubber stamped despite opposition from parish councillors.

In his report to Staffordshire Moorlands District Council, planning officer Benjamin Hurst said: “The applicants are travellers that have a nomadic way of life, particularly in respect of their work and employment.

"The family's ‘gypsy status’ for planning purposes has been previously accepted by the council. The existing caravan site that provides their accommodation was granted a planning permission last year."

Mr Hurst went on to describe the small building currently on site.

It measures just 4.2 metres by five metres, has a small kitchenette, a single toilet and a shower to service the three pitch caravan site.

“The building would be extended so that in addition to the existing kitchenette there would be an additional toilet and shower taking site total to two toilets and two showers and one separate ‘day room’," he continued.

“The day room would be available to all site occupants and, in particular, provide the children with space to study or be active when they can not be outside.

“The caravan site provides a settled base for the travelling families to return to in relation to their nomadic way of life.

"When the families cease using the site it is a condition of the planning permission that the utility building shall be removed.

"If the building were extended permission for a new larger building could be subject to a very similar condition that requires it to be removed when it is no longer needed.”

(Image: StokeOnTrentLive/ WS)

Standing in the way of the Price family and their new washing and cooking facilities was Checkley Parish Council.

In a searing statement criticising the proposal, parish clerk Siân Morgan-Owen summarised the council's "strong objections".

"The Parish Council would like to point out that if the extension is more than twice the size of the original building then surely it is no longer an 'extension!' she wrote.

"The fact that an extension has been requested implies that the travellers who occupy this site are no longer travellers but settlers which means the site is no longer being used for its intended purpose.

"The Parish Council also has concerns regarding the visual impact this much larger structure will have on the area and those living in close proximity."

Despite the parish council's attempts to block the build, the application was unanimously approved by district councillors.

Speaking to the planning committee, the applicant’s agent Roger Yarwood, said: “This is a fair report which sums up the situation. This is for a growing family’s needs. The council has been very fair.”
description: The Price family can now extend their wash facilities at home on Olive Tree Park in Cheadle, Staffordshire
